noun.meaning: The tapered, sharp end of a tool, weapon, or other object.
noun.example: It takes almost no force for one of these points or edges to cause a laceration

noun.subMeaning: A pointed flake or blade, especially one that has been worked.
noun.subExample: At Teviec in Brittany a male burial had two flint points embedded in his spine

noun.subMeaning: The tip of a person's chin as a spot for a blow.
noun.subExample: She concentrated hard to gather her wits, and when Frank paused, slammed a right uppercut to the point of his chin

noun.subMeaning: The prong of a deer's antler.
noun.subExample: Eight-point bucks almost certainly will remain plentiful

noun.meaning: A dot or other punctuation mark, in particular a full stop.
noun.example: Every punctuation point had better be right

noun.subMeaning: A decimal point.
noun.subExample: Six point nine percent, that's a nine-year high

noun.subMeaning: A dot or small stroke used in Semitic languages to indicate vowels or distinguish particular consonants.
noun.subExample: The vowel is sometimes written; and at others it is expressed by the point above the consonant

noun.subMeaning: A very small dot or mark.
noun.subExample: Millions of points of light scatter across the sky and are reflected in the waters below

noun.meaning: A particular spot, place, or position in an area or on a map, object, or surface.
noun.example: Being one of the highest points in the area, it is considered to be a sacred grove

noun.subMeaning: A particular moment in time or stage in a process.
noun.subExample: At some point during that long night they took a decision - and headed north

noun.subMeaning: The critical or decisive moment.
noun.subExample: Conversation ceases to resolve the internal contention between characters, words fail and the conflict comes to the point

noun.subMeaning: The verge or brink of (doing or being something)
noun.subExample: It is patently obvious that the health service is on the point of collapse

noun.subMeaning: A stage or level at which a change of state occurs.
noun.subExample: Boil until setting point is reached and then preserve in small sterilised jars

noun.subMeaning: A socket in a wall for connecting a device to an electrical supply or communications network.
noun.subExample: The larger room has a television point and plenty of space for a study desk or additional storage units

noun.subMeaning: (in geometry) something having position but not spatial extent, magnitude, dimension, or direction, for example the intersection of two lines.
noun.subExample: By joining all the points of tangency we construct a line ABC, which is an output expansion path

noun.meaning: A single item or detail in an extended discussion, list, or text.
noun.example: He gives a summary of some of the main points which were discussed

noun.subMeaning: An argument or idea.
noun.subExample: He also made the point that farmers are not aware of the Social Welfare entitlements they might have

noun.subMeaning: The significant or essential element of something being planned or discussed.
noun.subExample: The whole point of her character was that she was a tough survivor

noun.subMeaning: Advantage or purpose that can be gained from doing something.
noun.subExample: There's no point in splashing out on expensive designer gear if your skin is as rough as sandpaper

noun.subMeaning: Relevance or effectiveness.
noun.subExample: His remarks were always full of point, clearness, and good sense

noun.subMeaning: A distinctive feature or characteristic, typically a good one, of a person or thing.
noun.subExample: The reception rooms, large garden and garage are likely to prove key selling points

noun.meaning: (in sports and games) a mark or unit of scoring awarded for success or performance.
noun.example: They established a lead at the top of the table which at one stage reached thirteen points

noun.subMeaning: A unit used in measuring value, achievement, or extent.
noun.subExample: His gains averaged just three percentage points

noun.subMeaning: An advantage or success in an argument or discussion.
noun.subExample: I felt then like I would never go back to work until we had won our point

noun.subMeaning: A unit of credit towards an award or benefit.
noun.subExample: I wouldn't let a few points off of my credit score keep me from purchasing a home

noun.subMeaning: A percentage of the profits from a film or recording offered to certain people involved in its production.
noun.subExample: Because he is a producer as well as an actor you can be sure he has points in the film

noun.subMeaning: (in piquet) the longest suit in a player's hand, containing a specified number of up to eight cards.
noun.subExample: The number of cards in the suit is announced (e.g. ‘point of 5’) and it scores this number

noun.subMeaning: A unit of weight (2 mg) for diamonds.
noun.subExample: The point system provides a convenient  and more impressive  way of describing diamonds that are less than one carat

noun.subMeaning: A unit of varying value, used in quoting the price of stocks, bonds, or futures.
noun.subExample: When message boards first took off in the mid 90s, postings like that could send stock up or down several points in a day

noun.subMeaning: A value assigned to certain cards (4 points for an ace, 3 for a king, 2 for a queen, and 1 for a jack, sometimes with extra points for long or short suits) by a player in assessing the strength of their hand.
noun.subExample: The result of the hand depends on the number of card points won by the opponents

noun.meaning: Each of thirty-two directions marked at equal distances round a compass.
noun.example: Arrayed around it like points on the compass rose were sections of the house

noun.subMeaning: A direction towards the horizon corresponding to the direction marked on a compass.
noun.subExample: Having taken in the view from all points of the compass, I was about to leave when I spotted some pay phones

noun.subMeaning: Unspecified places considered in terms of their direction from a specified place.
noun.subExample: Passengers for points west could go through without stopping to change cars

noun.meaning: A narrow piece of land jutting out into the sea.
noun.example: I walked alone south along the beach toward Cape Point

noun.meaning: A junction of two railway lines, with a pair of linked tapering rails that can be moved laterally to allow a train to pass from one line to the other.
noun.example: The first train to pass over the points was the 7am service to Glasgow

noun.meaning: A unit of measurement for type sizes and spacing (in the UK and US 0.351 mm, in Europe 0.376 mm).
noun.example: Because monitors display at different resolutions, 12-point type on one screen could approximate 14-point type on another

noun.meaning: A fielding position on the off side near the batsman.
noun.example: You will usually find the best fielder in the team fielding at point

noun.subMeaning: A fielder at the point position.
noun.subExample: Point does not chat with cover-point

noun.subMeaning: Either of two areas to the left and right of the net, just inside the blue line where it meets the boards.
noun.subExample: Usually the players at the two points are the defensemen

noun.subMeaning: A position at the front of the court, usually manned by the guard who sets up the team's defence.
noun.subExample: Typically, shooting guards are taller than point guards and more athletic

noun.meaning: (in a motor vehicle) each of a set of electrical contacts in the distributor.
noun.example: I cleaned the points and the bike is now rideable

noun.meaning: A small leading party of an advanced guard of troops.
noun.example: He sent three of his men ahead as a ‘point’

noun.subMeaning: The position at the head of a column or wedge of troops.
noun.subExample: Who wants to walk point today

noun.meaning: The extremities of an animal, typically a horse or cat, such as the face, paws, and tail of a Siamese cat.
noun.example: The mask, legs and tail should all show clear tabby markings which should be the same colour on all points

noun.meaning: A spot to which a straight run is made.
noun.example: These marshy channels are the invariable point of any hunted boar

noun.subMeaning: A straight run.
noun.subExample: The hounds made an eight mile point in a little over 45 minutes

noun.meaning: A tagged piece of ribbon or cord used for lacing a garment or attaching a hose to a doublet.
noun.example: He began to untruss his points

noun.meaning: A short piece of cord at the lower edge of a sail for tying up a reef.
noun.example: The top-sails are always reefed with points

noun.meaning: The action or position of a dog in pointing.
noun.example: Some dogs tend to exhibit signs of jealousy on seeing another dog on point

noun.meaning: An important phrase or subject, especially in a contrapuntal composition.
noun.example: Stokowski changes gear at points as if he decided tempos needed geared up

verb.meaning: Direct someone's attention towards something by extending one's finger or something held in one's hand.
verb.example: Trent flung his arm out, pointing at the buffalo

verb.subMeaning: Indicate a particular time, direction, or reading.
verb.subExample: We reverse down another road and see a sign for the Forest but it's pointing in another direction entirely

verb.subMeaning: Direct or aim (something) at someone or something.
verb.subExample: Two men burst into the crowded shop and one pointed the weapon at staff and customers

verb.subMeaning: Face or be turned in a particular direction.
verb.subExample: Four giant white spotlights were illuminated from the top of each gantry, pointing upwards towards the sky

verb.subMeaning: (of a dog) indicate the presence of (game) by standing rigid while looking towards it.
verb.subExample: Both dogs found and pointed a group of about seven or eight birds

verb.meaning: Cite a fact or situation as evidence of something.
verb.example: He points to the fact that people are still coming forward to risk their lives for this experiment

verb.subMeaning: (of a fact or situation) indicate that (something) is likely to happen or be the case.
verb.subExample: There are many facts pointing to sweeping climatic changes in the Earth's distant past

verb.subMeaning: Give force or emphasis to (words or actions)
verb.subExample: The wealth of illustrative material drawn from the political and commercial history of the world with which he pointed his arguments, gave them a touch of human interest

verb.meaning: Extend (the toes or feet) in line with the leg by tensing the foot and ankle in such a way as to form a point.
verb.example: Brendon is the first one to stir, sitting up and stretching, pointing his leather-booted toes

verb.meaning: Fill the joints of (brickwork or masonry) with smoothly finished mortar.
verb.example: Ideally you should point the brickwork after the bricks have been laid long enough for the mortar to start to set

verb.meaning: Give a sharp, tapered point to.
verb.example: Shape the sticks into batons by shaving off the square corners and pointing the ends

verb.meaning: Insert points in (written text of Semitic languages).
verb.example: This variety of reading arises chiefly from the different modes of pointing the Hebrew words

verb.subExample: I have found this discussion very interesting with solid guidance for pointing the psalms and choosing psalm tones
